participants.participant: Wolfram Schmitt, Head of Investor Relations
Anthony di Iorio, Chief Financial Officer
Dr. Wolfram Schmitt, Head of Investor Relations

plist.p: Good morning and good evening. I am Sherry, the operator for this conference. Welcome to the second quarter analysts conference call. Please note that for the duration of the presentation all participants will be in listen-only mode and the conference is being recorded. After the presentation there will an opportunity to ask questions.
At this time I'd like to turn the conference over Dr. Wolfram Schmitt, Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

Yes. Thank you, Sherry and good morning to everybody. This is Deutsche Bank's second quarter call. Earlier today we have issued our earnings release, our financial data suppliant, the full interim report and I trust you all have in front of you the set of PowerPoint slides which will support this call.

I have to draw your attention to the leader disclaimer as usual regarding forward-looking statements. I trust you have read them all and carefully and so therefore I don't have to read it out. It's an integral part of all our disclosure documents.

It's my pleasure to introduce Tony di Iorio, CFO of Deutsche Bank, who will in good tradition brief you on this call on our quarterly financials. But I have to add that for all of us in Deutsche Bank it is a very special call, because it's Tony's last analyst briefing due to his retirement end of September as you all know.
Tony, on this note let me hand over to you. The air is yours.

Thank you, Wolfram, and good morning everyone and thank your for joining us on the call. This morning we announced our third -- second quarter results and if you start from the PowerPoint presentation, I'll flip through these charts and then we'll be happy to answer questions when we are done.

Group performance was income before taxes of 600, net income of a comparable amount to diluted earnings per share. The highlights of the quarter's performance are probably in CB&S [Corporate Banking and Securities] where we reported a 300 million loss for the quarter despite the fact that we took mark-downs of 2.3 billion which we'll discuss a in little more detail in a minute and we believe that result show the strength of many of our underlying businesses.

The stable businesses: GTB [Global Transaction Banking] and the PCAM [Private Clients and Asset Management] business reported income before taxes of 900 indicating the results of our investments in those businesses and the resilience of those businesses even in difficult market such as we have experienced. Corporate investments had income of 300 million: some of that was from the sales of industrial holdings; some of it was from dividends, the second quarter is the normal height of the dividend season here in Germany; and it also had some mark-downs on our option position to buy more shares in the Chinese bank, Huaxia.

Capital risk and liquidity show continued strength. Our Tier 1 ratio at the end of the quarter was 9.3% well above our eight to nine range that we have targeted. There were significant reductions in exposures and we'll go through those charts shortly. We still have ready access to the funding markets. We have raised over 40 billion in the first half of this year in the capital markets with debt with a maturity of greater than one year which stabilizes our funding source and we have reduced our balance sheet by 159 million from a restated number in the first quarter adjusted for some net downs that we have not been taking previously, but I will describe that in a second.

If you turn to the next page, you will see the summary and I won't spend too much time on this. Revenues were down, but that's after the 2.3 billion of mark-downs. I want to focus for a minute on the tax line, because the tax line was a small net credit and this is due to three factors.

The first is the geographic mix of our earnings because of the mark-downs, we experienced losses in some entities in the United States. The tax rate in the United States is the highest of all of our geographic tax rates. So that reduces our global rate mix.

In addition to that we had a benefit after the successful resolution of some pending tax matters, which we had provided for and we have released what we had provided. And finally we had a negative effect because of the decrease in our share price; we released some previously recorded tax benefits on the deduction from the amortization of our equity compensation. So despite that charge in the quarter, the other two factors reduced our tax rate to a small negative.

If we turn to the next page, you will see the -- where we took the mark-downs of the 2.3 and what we did with exposures during the quarter. And I am not going to read each of these because we'll go through them as we go through the businesses, but on the exposures that we're going to show you in detail, we have 2 billion of which 200 million was in our leveraged finance portfolio and the balance was in our sales and trading businesses.
In addition to that we had about 100 – just under 100 million of write-downs on some European RMBS securities that are not shown on this chart.

And we also took an impairment; this is the third straight quarter in which we have recorded an impairment on available for sale securities related to our consolidated conduits. We have talked about this in the past. And this charge had been reflected in the equivalent of other comprehensive income. We deemed an event to have occurred and therefore transferred that from our equity section through the P&L and that was about 200 million.

If you go to the next chart, you will see our net revenues are down 39% to 5.4 billion. And that -- a lot of that has to do with the mark-downs and with the strength continuing in our stable business.

If you go to the next chart, which looks at expenses and I want to spend sometime on this. Our expenses are down 23%. And they are -- if you look at the compensation number, this is driven by lower performance during the period. And as we've indicated in prior meetings, we look and true-up on a year-to-date basis, the impacts of the performance and the schemes, the general accrual schemes we have for compensation.

When we look at accruing incentive compensation, we look at two primary factors. The first is segmental performance and we accrue at different rates in each segment consistent with compensation levels in the market in our different businesses. But we also look at group performance and if overall group performance is not at a standard or a level that management believes is appropriate then we always keep the option of adjusting the segmental accruals. And we -- the barometer we use to make this evaluation is our overall comp ratio and you'll see later or in the disclosures that our comp ratio for the quarter was just over 50%, so it's about 50%. So that's how we approach it and we true that up on a year-to-date basis each quarter.

Compensation in this quarter, in the first quarter also included some accelerated equity amortization and we've mentioned this. And this has to do with grants made in the first quarter to individuals who were eligible for early retirement, therefore don't have to provide service for those and we – so therefore we expands them when granted. That number was a first quarter event, we did not have – we have a comparable number each quarter, but it's those people who in that quarter have reached that early retirement, so the number is decreased by a significant amount.

If you look at the dark blue the general administrative expenses you will see that likewise that is down. And that's due to a series of factors. The first is favorable FX movements in respect to the euro, the second is lower litigation accruals compared to the second quarter last year and the third is cost containment initiatives and this is principally in discretionary areas. We look – we have looked at professional service fees, travel, entertainment and similar expense and have seen good reductions in those.

In addition there was a charge in the second quarter last year, related to the renovation project, currently ongoing in our headquarters in Frankfurt and that was a second quarter '07 event that was not repeated.

There is a small 100 million shown at the bottom, which we've been isolating that was a credit in the first quarter for policy holder benefits and claims in respect to Abbey Life, the closed book insurance company that we have acquired in our global markets business. This quarter it was a charge and that has in both quarters zero net pre-tax income effect, because there is a comparable amount in revenues.

If we look at segment results, you will see on page seven, the description of what those results are and I'll go though and – page nine; I am sorry, page nine – and I'll go through each of the business segments in a minute, but let me just focus on consolidation and adjustments.

We reported a loss of 176 million there, the bulk of that loss is due the true up of our management accounts on which the segments are based to IFRS. And that number could go up or down depending on what happens in the individual businesses.

If we look CB&S, CB&S and we mentioned this in our summary, reported a pre-tax loss of 311, but that is after taking, reflecting mark-downs of 2.3 billion. We saw solid volumes in our flow, sales and trading businesses, including our finance business, our FX business and in equities our -- some of our cash equity business, as well as in our prime services businesses and we will go through those in a minute.

We had lower revenues in origination and advisory, including the 200 million charge for leveraged finance and we saw substantial reductions in exposures. Some of our peers have shown the chart similar to page 11 and so we thought we would also include it.

Looking at a comparison of what the pro forma revenues would be in CB&S, absent the mark-downs. And if you saw in the prior page, we reported revenues of 2.2 billion, the extreme right bar. If we were to add back to that, the 2.3 billion of mark-downs net of hedges, we would have had pro forma revenues of 4.4, which is within 900 million, less than a billion from the second quarter last year. And I want to emphasize the second quarter last year was our strongest second quarter in our history, so we are comparing against a very strong standard.

If you go to Sales and Trading debt, you will see that our revenues were down to 602 million for the quarter. And this is where 2 billion of the mark-downs are reflected. If you look at the businesses that contributed, we have strong results from the FX, rates and money market businesses with strong client flows.

One of the things we're seeing not only in this business but throughout, and I'll comment on this in equities in one of the businesses in a minute, has been an increase in market share and a migration of clients to Deutsche Bank from many of our peers that are having or experiencing more difficulties in the markets than we are.

Now our credit business revenues are down, and this was due to a reduction in our structured credit business. We took some of the mark-downs in a monoline business against this activity. And we also – however, we did see a good flow in our customer flow business.

Commodities was down and this is primarily due to trading losses in the U.S. power market. Commercial real estate is down, we took mark-downs here, but we are continuing to reduce the risk and in our RMBS this was the largest mark-down area we took, about 1 billion, and this has principally been in the Alt-A portfolio. Many of our peers began aggressively selling down their RMBS positions in the second quarter and we as others experienced a mark-down here, because of the drop in the valuations in the market.

If we would go to Equities, you'll see that our revenues are down there as well. Our equity derivative business saw reduced activity. And likewise, we have a smaller ongoing effect in correlation from the first quarter much smaller in size, but yet continuing.

Cash equities, very challenging markets, but we see continued growth in North America. The Prime services business is the other business where we've seen migration of flight to quality, so to speak or how we would express it with not only existing clients doing more business with us but likewise, with new clients that we previously had not done much business. Designated proprietary trading is flat to the second quarter last year.

Origination and Advisory, revenues were down. Our Advisory business M&A volumes are down for the quarter, however, we had our strongest ever ranking in announced volumes, number four globally, as is shown on the chart, number two in Europe, Middle East and Asia and number four in the United States. So we've maintained and in some places increased our market share, albeit the reduction in overall volumes.

Equity origination we saw the same trend with declining market values, issuance of equities likewise, with the reduction in the M&A activity has declined. We're happy with the performance of our investment grade debt origination where we've been -- we've shown an increase in the revenues for the comparable period and we've maintained a top five ranking. And in our high-yield and leveraged loan business this was characterized principally by the mark-downs we took -- although we did show healthy net interest margin offsetting, so we took 200 million of losses approximately, in the mark-downs, but that was offset by just over 150 million of net interest margin.

That net interest margin has been declining as we derisk the portfolio. And we'll continue on that trend as we continue derisking unless we – the business comes back to where it was previously, although we believe, risk-wise and the transactions we're seeing in the market, are being structured very differently and many of them are coming from the strategic buyers rather than the financial buyers.

The next several pages deal with our exposures and the progress on our exposures; these are detailed here, but also in more detail in our interim report, as well as with more extensive narrative than what is here. The first is CDO subprime exposure. This exposure, and the next one on the residential mortgage-backed securities, the data that's shown here assumes the loss we would have if 100% of the underlying assets defaulted, and there was a zero recovery from that default.
As you can see, our gross exposures are down, and our hedges are about where they were, and they are down slightly, as they've been readjusted. So, our net exposure is about flat.

We'll spend a little more time on the next chart, which shows our RMBS business, and you can see the reduction in the Alt-A portfolio of about 1 billion. That is principally from our mark-downs. On the CDO book, we were able to liquidate positions. In the RMBS book, the liquidations were fewer. So the bulk of the change is the mark-down.

As I indicated earlier, there was extensive selling in large blocks by many of our peers during the second quarter. This put considerable pressure on values and that is reflected in the mark-downs we took of about a billion in this quarter.

We've monitored this risk very carefully. We're looking to do other things to de-risk. I would mention that there's still a considerable size, albeit it lower, and therefore there is basis risk between these positions and the hedges. Many of our monoline hedges are also in this area. And we'll talk about that on the next chart, as to what we've done there.

The monoline exposure in the Alt-A book, you can see, has increased from March to June. And this would parallel the change in the value of those positions. And on a total basis, therefore, we're up. On a net basis, however, we have provided over 500 million for potential credit impairments on this monoline activity in the quarter, and we derive these numbers on a fundamental name-by-name analysis, looking at ratings, in many cases there're some very extensive discussions with the monolines as to their situations and claim-paying ability. And we're now have total allowances against this book of 800 million, of which about 700 million is taken against the exposures on the left-hand side of the chart. The balance is against other monoline exposures. And if you look at the first comment on the right, you'll see that that exposure is an additional 2.2 billion.
In our interim report, we've included an additional disclosure this quarter for the first time, which analyses this monoline exposure by rating band, and so I'd reference you to that.

If we turn to our Commercial Real Estate business on page 18, there is a summary of our traded loans. And you can see that our net exposure -- or carrying value, rather -- is down to 10.7 billion. I do want to add -- make a couple of comments as to comparability to the prior period.

First is, in the prior disclosures we did not include exposures in Asia, which we have for the first time here, and those exposures are less than a billion, Asia Pac. In addition to that, we had in place some synthetic risk reduction in the first quarter that we did not use -- did not put on the table, showing the reduction of what impact that would have, but we're including it on this chart.

Overall, those adjustments would not have changed the trend, and we're showing a drop of considerable size on a pre-reserve or pre-allowance basis, from 16.4 to 12. And on a net basis, down from 14.4 to 10.7, so whichever way you look at it, considerable.

We took 543 of additional gross markdowns during the period. You can see that at the bottom of the chart. And we had some hedges against that. If you look at the distribution, of our remaining exposure, net exposure, you'll see that the largest area of exposure we have is in Germany, and the reduction has been most felt in North America, where we're now down to less than half.

Since the end of June, we've had additional reductions that are not reflected on this chart, and we'll be reporting on those when the third quarter events occur. We're continuing to look to sell. I'm sorry, that's leveraged finance, not the commercial real estate, commercial real estate does reflect through the synthetics, the others, I apologize for that.

On leveraged finance, the next chart, we have had continued reduction here. These numbers are comparable to the way we presented them in the prior quarter. You can see that there were considerable sales of 7.2 billion. There are some new commitments being made and I alluded to these earlier when we talked about the origination business and we've also had some cancellations.

That brings our carrying value at the end of the quarter to 24.5 billion, as I indicated earlier there've been some additional reductions since the end of June which we will report on the third quarter and these bring our exposure to approximately 50% of where it was at the end of August last year so very considerable activity here.

I should add, because there were some questions at the last meeting and in some of your reports, you raised the question as to level at which we're valuing these comparables to our peers. Every week we publish a report showing the prior week's sales activity and one of the parameters that I look at that report is on the sales we have made, how close our realized profit or loss is to our unrealized i.e. our marks. And I can tell you that we have been selling positions through July at approximately our marks and to me that's says that our very thorough analysis process and there is a lot of judgment involved in most of these valuations, are producing results that are comparable to what we're liquidating positions in the market.

In both, the commercial real estate as well as the leveraged finance we've included additional disclosures which will show you the industry areas to which these commitments or loans apply and I think from looking at that chart you will see that there are some notable areas that we are not exposed to – notable industries, automotive for example and that could make a difference between your estimates as to what these mar-downs or carrying values are and the actual values that we place on them.

Although, the actual values are ultimately determined by what we can sell for in the market I want to reiterate that the values at which we are selling are at or near, with very little difference, our marks.

If we turn to the next chart, on the stable businesses, you will see that there is continuing solid performance, 854 million, which is up from the second quarter last year. And I will go through these in detail.

First in terms of GTB, very slonge trajectory. 283 million, up 15% on our income before taxes from the prior year second quarter. And this has been characterized by growth in our custody business, in our trade finance business and we've seen this growth in revenues despite the effects of lower interest rates and the weakening dollar, particularly.

We announced in July, the acquisition of the Dutch mid cap business of being -- coming out of ABN as per the large three-way acquisition there. And this indicates our strategy of looking for strategic expansion in stable businesses where we see values that will generate positive shareholder return within a reasonable period of time.

If you turn to Asset and Wealth Management [AWM], here we've had a decline from the prior quarter -- prior period quarter by 17%. And this is due to two primary factors. The first is our fees that are asset based were lower, consistent with declines and deterioration of markets, particularly in the equity markets and this affects our mutual fund business specifically. And also a reduction in activity in our real estate business, particularly where in the prior periods we either showed performance fees, which we said were lumpy, and in the current markets those are down. As well as reductions in both the sales of businesses that were reflected in the second quarter last year, which we disclosed on one of our Australian businesses, as well as the sale of investments that were held in this business either into funds or into the market.

On the positive side, we showed net new money during the quarter in invested assets of 8 billion and for the year-to-date in the Asset and Wealth Management business of 15 billion. We think that this is a very positive and strong result. In talking to the people in these businesses, particularly the Private Wealth Management business, we are seeing a flow out of other banks that are currently experiencing problems in a greater extent than we are. And we believe that we have opportunities here to further strengthen these businesses particularly in the Private Wealth Management arena.

As far as PBC [Private & Business Clients] is concerned, we have an increase of 11%, 328 million, above -- 11% above the second quarter last year. Revenues of almost 1.5 billion in the second quarter and this came from increased margins on both our deposits and loans. But, particularly on the deposit side where we've seen active campaigns in our retail branch network, raising deposits. I'll show you a chart later where we talk about stable funding and as a bank with a large retail presence, we have opportunities to provide more stable funding in this area. We've mounted fairly active campaigns here in Germany and we've been very successful, particularly in our Norrisbank business where our deposit flows have been very strong.

We've also seen increase in insurance brokerage and a lot of this has to do with some retirement products here in Germany as well as in our payments and accounts services businesses and that's been somewhat offset by a reduction in the securities brokerage business consistent with the reduction in the market -- in the market conditions.

As far as net new money here, we've seen 3 billion of inflows in the second quarter and 7 billion for the whole year. If you turn to the next chart you'll see what has driven our change in invested assets in PCAM and we're slightly above where we were at the end of the quarter and as you can see on the chart that comes from both from negative performance in the market as well as some other activities which have to do with sales of businesses, transfer of businesses.

Modest FX effect this quarter; in prior quarters, the FX effects were much stronger. And you can see that the 10 billion of net new money in PCAM again this portends well, we think, for the future and we anticipate continuing net new money coming in to the bank.

If we turn to Risk, Capital and Liquidity, our provisions for the quarter – and I'm on page 26 here, provisions for the quarter were 135 million and if you look at the bottom of the page you'll see the business areas that drove that. In CIB [Corporate and Investment Bank] we had a net recovery though lower than where we were in the second quarter last year of 9 million but an increase in PCAM from 124 to 145.

This increase comes from two principle factors. The first is the growth in our consumer finance business and as volumes grow credit costs would grow with them. And this we saw particularly in Poland which is a key strategic buildup area for us and our credit business -- consumer credit business there is performing very well, as well as increased credit costs in Spain where we've seen some softening in the market and those are reflect.

If we look at our problem loans on the next page you will see that under the IFRS definition of an impaired loan, we're down to the level where we were in the second quarter of last year, 2.5 billion. Our coverage ratio is approximately the same at 65%.

For transparency and for reference we also show on this chart, the difference between the impaired loans and the problem loans. The problem loans are under the SEC definition, U.S.-GAAP definition and because we report that in our interim and 20-F reports, we've included it here for your reference.

If we turn to the Tier I ratio and this is something that shows significant strength, we've had yet another increase to 9.3 billion and -- 9.3%, I apologize, with risk weighted assets of 305 billion. And I would mention as far as our dividend assumptions are concerned, we continue to reflect in our net -- in our Tier I capital a reduction for the dividend on pro rata basis equal to the €4.50 that we paid last year.

As I said in the first quarter call this is not a commitment to pay that dividend, but it is a prudent treatment and in some respects it shows the strength of this 9.3 number because it was not achieved by changing our dividend accrual or by other means. So it's something I would reflect on and we'll be monitoring the dividend as we go through. The dividend decision is one base on recommendation in the beginning of next year by the Management Board and has to be ratified by the Supervisory Board.

Balance sheet size has been an issue of much discussion and in fact we've had reports from many of you raising the question and we do hear you. I would like to reiterate that the principle benchmark we use is risk weighted assets and if you look at the prior page you will see the achievements that we've made there. But we hear you and we are looking to do some things as well in balance sheet size. What we've done in this chart is shown, several things. It's a very busy chart, and I will try to give you a highlight -- a high level view of it.

At the end of March of this year, we reported assets of 2.3 billion. Subsequent to March, we went back and reviewed the treatments of netting that we were applying under IFRS and we identified additional netting of 156 billion that was possible. So want to show the transparency of the number we reported previously to the number that you will see in our interim report now.

So the 2.305 billion has been reduced to -- 2 trillion -- I am sorry. I will get my millions, trillions and billions mixed here. The 2.3 trillion we reported at the end of March has been adjusted in our interim reports to 2.150 trillion. And we wanted to show you that bridge so that when you went back into the reports and looked at your models it was clear that -- what drove that.

However, during the quarter, there was some further reduction of 159 billion, most of it coming in the positive mark-to-markets from derivatives, but also in trading securities and in the reverse repo line. So from the numbers you were using to calculate ratios previously we're down 314 billion although, only 159 billion of that is due to activities. The bank has recently asked Stefan Krause who will succeed me as CFO effective October 1, to head a project working with the businesses to find opportunities to reduce the balance sheet further, consistent with our goals of growing revenues and growing solid performing businesses and Stefan will report on that to you when he produces his first analyst call in the third quarter -- for the third quarter of this year.

One of the issues we do want to highlight is, it is tricky using gross balance sheet numbers. And we have mentioned this to many of you and I know we have not convinced you, but in our persistent effort to make the point – I hope we don't bother you by this – we are going to show you the calculation again. If you look at the prior page, the fair value of our derivatives as of June 30 was 640 billion.

If you really look at the credit risk inherent in that portfolio, you would see that it's a whole lot less. There is -- there are legally enforceable master netting agreements that we have available to us. Many of these derivatives are with exchanges. Where we have a difference after netting, we do ask our counterparts to provide collateral if we are in a net receivable position and we have some of these derivatives with sovereigns and other public sector entities. If we were to adjust for those effects, the exposed credit risk on this portfolio is 77 billion.

I should also add that in most cases because of the collateral, much of the gross or the net exposure provides funding or other collateral that we can use to hypothecate and raise funding. So the funding impact and the credit impact of this large mark-to-market in our derivatives book has a very different risk profile from assets that we or others may carry in other categories.

If we continue on funding, you'll see the effects of our -- what's happened to our stable funding base and we continue to strengthen it. Since June of last year, we have transferred substantial amounts of short-term funding, dependence on overnight funding, to more stable capital markets and retail deposits as well as fiduciary balances. And I talked about both of the capital markets before. We've had 40 billion of long-term debt issued so far this year with maturities medium-term to long-term debt of greater than a year. And I talked earlier in PBC, but somewhat in PWM [Private Wealth Management] of the efforts to increase our stable deposit base.

The next pages raises another very interesting phenomenon which has not yet translated itself into equity evaluations. But if you look at what's happened to our five-year CDS spread what we can borrow money for. Our spread albeit higher than where it was a year ago is substantially lower than many of our peers at 63 basis points. And we draw your attention to that.
That's the end of my prepared remarks. The highlights here are similar what's on the first page. So I'll stop and turn it back over to Wolfram, then we will entertain questions.
Thank you Tony and Sherry I will hand it over to you direct.
. The first question is from Mr. Michael Rohr of MainFirst. Please go ahead, sir.
Yes. Hi. Very good morning. Three questions from my side.

First of all in terms of the underlying fixed income revenue, if we adjust for the one-off that you had in the quarter in secondary fixed income we are just talking a 5% year-over -year decline and I just wanted to know apart from the strong flow business that you had, how much do you think is due to the market situation i.e. people seeking Deutsche Bank for liquidity management, hedging and other trades that they need in the current market environment?

Second question which refers to page 12 of your presentation again, if you could quantify the decline in the structured products revenues that you had and potentially elaborate a bit more on the trends going forward for this and how much this might influence the revenue line going forward, although it might be relatively small item?

And the final question, more a personal view question to you, Tony, and how far do you think are you in terms of de-leveraging at Deutsche bank in terms of balance sheet size and how comfortable do you feel in the environment right now? Thank you.

Underlying revenues in fixed income, we think a substantial -- we think that there are two basic drivers. The first is our footprint, the breadth and depth of our relationships because if we didn't have that then nothing else would happen and nothing else would matter. So we have a very strong franchise and we've said this all along. There have some issues and dislocations in the market that have affected the revenues and performance. But we continue to be convinced that we do have the strong depth and breadth globally by product, by any measure that you would look at the abilities of our people.

We are seeing increased market share as well. I wouldn't quantify that right now. And we are seeing clients migrating to us. Now how much of that has to do with leaving where they are, how much of that has to do with our product and our platform, I don't that I am – I can give reasonable rational answer to that, but we are seeing the effect and we do measure the increased market share and we are seeing it. So I believe your hypothesis that the decline is small and that's due to of flow of clients, we believe is correct.

As far as the structured business is concerned, we're definitely seeing a reduction in that activity. We are looking to do some things and we believe that looking forward into the future at least for some time we'll see more straightforward plain vanilla product offerings. We believe that the structured product business is not over and our belief is founded on some very basic facts. Bank capital is under pressure. Businesses around the world have demand for continued funding and if it can't come from the banks, it has to come from other sources and we believe that one of those sources is structured credit, perhaps in a different form from what had been offered structured previously, probably a different risk profile and other parameters but we don't see this business as over.

With regard to deleveraging, I don't think we want to forecast a number as to where our balance sheet would reach. There is a lot of dynamics going on. Some of that has to do with what's happening with values in the market because if we have positions that increase or decrease in value, that affects the balance sheet size, but we do have a program underway. As I said it's got the new CFO or the future CFOs leadership, so it's got board member leadership and we'll be reporting and he'll be reporting to you on that as we go forward.
All right. Thank you very much.
You're welcome, Michael.
Can I please add that you limit to one question or keep it really crisp because I know we have a lot of in the queue. Please go ahead.
The next question is from Mr. Huw van Steenis of Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead, sir.
Morning everyone. I just wanted to ask just a series of questions around the balance sheet.
Number one, a number of banks have been suggesting they think there might be a new treatment for trading book assets over the coming two or three years. Any views on that?

Jamie Diamond recently was very critical of the calculation of risk weighted assets for some of the U.S. investment banks and I was wondering if you share some of his concerns and what that may mean for yourself?

Then lastly, we've obviously now seen the U.S. investment banks' balance sheets for the first time. What's interesting is their assets to risk weighted assets ratio is roughly 3:1, I think yours is about 6.5:1. If I even adjust yours to U.S. GAAP basis it's about 4.5:1 and I was just wondering what you think contributes to why your assets to RWAs [Risk Weighted Assets] is so much higher than some of the U.S. peers? Thank you.
Huw, can you just clarify the first question on the trading book treatment?

A number of the European banks are suggesting they thought that the Basel committee may have another look at what the right weightings would be for the way some assets on the trading book are treated.
Oh, the risk weightings.
Yes, the risk weightings.
I'm sorry; I thought you meant the fair value treatment.
No, no I apologize. I'm sorry for the lack of clarity. Thanks.
